chapter.title: &dcache; Webadmin-Interface
chapter.para: This part describes how to configure the &cell-webadmin;-interface which is a replacement for the old &cell-httpd;-service and offers additional features to admins like sending admin-commands equal to those of &cell-admin; to chosen cells.
For authentication and authorisation it offers usage of username/password (currently KAuth-File) or grid-certificates talking to &cell-gplazma;. It also offers a non-authenticated, read-only mode.

If you are logged in as admin it is possible to send a command to multiple pools or a whole poolgroup in one go. It is even possible to send a command to any &dcache;-Cell. Also, there is information like their size, their id and used space on linkgroups and spacetokens available.

From the technical point of view the &cell-webadmin;-interface uses a Jetty-Server which is embedded in an ordinary &dcache;-cell. It is using apache-wicket (a webfrontend-framework) and YAML (a CSS-Template Framework). The application is wired up by a Spring IOC-Container.

section.title: Installation
section.para: For the authenticated mode a configured &cell-gplazma; is required (see also ). The user may either authenticate by presenting his grid certificate or by entering a valid username/password combination. This way it is possible to login even if the user does not have a grid-certificate. The KAuth-File has to be on the same machine as the &cell-webadmin; for this to work with &cell-gplazma1;, because it is the only available username/password login mechanism of &cell-gplazma1;. For a non-authenticated &cell-webadmin; you just need to add the &cell-webadmin; service to a domain and configure the port &cell-webadmin; will listen on - webadminHttpPort.

For authenticated mode the host certificate has to be imported into the &dcache;-keystore. In the grid world host certificates are usually signed by national Grid-CAs. Refer to the documentation provided by the Grid-CA to find out how to request a certificate. To import them into the &dcache;-keystore use this command: &prompt-root; /opt/d-cache/bin/dcache import hostcert Now you have to initialise your truststore (this is the certificate-store used for the SSL connections) by using this command: &prompt-root; /opt/d-cache/bin/dcache import cacerts Webadmin-interface uses the same truststore as &cell-webDAV;, so maybe you can skip this step.

You can enable the &cell-webadmin; interface by adding the service (&cell-webadmin;) to a domain; for example: [webadminDomain] [webadminDomain/webadmin] webadminHttpsPort=8443 webadminHttpPort=8080 webadminDCacheInstanceName=coolName webadminAuthenticated=true webadminAdminGid=1000

The most important value is webadminAdminGid, because it configures who is allowed to alter dCache behaviour, which certainly should not be everyone: # ---- GID a user has to have to be considered an Admin of webadmininterface # # When a user has this GID he can become an Admin for webadmininterface webadminAdminGid=1000 To see all webadmin specific property values have a look at /opt/d-cache/share/defaults/webadmin.properties.
For information on &cell-gplazma; configuration have a look at and for a special example .
After startup of webadmin you can reach it via http://example.com:8080/webadmin.
